results.title: Mikhail Kaufman in Dziga Vertov’s Chelovek s kinoapparatom (Man with a Movie Camera)
results.brief_description: Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. It inspired both cinéma vérité and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s intimate portraits of society and herself.
results.title_for_label: Mikhail Kaufman in Dziga Vertov’s Chelovek s kinoapparatom (Man with a Movie Camera)
results.description: Documentarians develop camera techniques to access, interpret and compose notions of truth. Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. In the 1960s, it inspired the development of both cinéma vérité (“truthful cinema”) and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s use of a handheld camera to create a portrait of society and herself.
description_for_label: Documentarians develop camera techniques to access, interpret and compose notions of truth. Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. In the 1960s, it inspired the development of both cinéma vérité (“truthful cinema”) and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s use of a handheld camera to create a portrait of society and herself.

results.title: 'Tank Man' protestor, Tiananmen Square
results.brief_description: ‘An unknown man stared down a column of tanks the morning after the Chinese government massacred pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in 1989. His fate and identity remain unknown, but the moment – captured on film and smuggled to safety – has become a symbol of defiance.

constellations_primary.name: Uncovering the truth
constellations_primary.description: The images of Tank Man during the Tiananmen Square protests in 1989 were captured by photojournalists and shared around the world. The work of journalists has been key to uncovering abuses of power and are rich material for fictional and factual movies and TV.

constellations_other.name: Spectacle
constellations_other.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. From newsreel shorts in cinemas before the show to the arrival of TV, nightly news and the 24-hour news cycle to social media, news has become a spectacle.

results.description: ‘An unknown man stared down a column of tanks the morning after the Chinese government massacred pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in 1989. His fate and identity remain unknown, but the moment – captured on film and smuggled to safety – has become a symbol of defiance.
